[10] "Review from #geekysumit.#############MOTO G4 PLAY#############IN BOX CONTENTS=================1. HANDSET(W/O BATTERY)2. STANDARD CHEAP PLASTIC EARPHONES3. POWER ADAPTER (TRAVEL CHARGER) FAST CHARGER4. DOCUMENTATIONS AND PAPER WORKS5. BATTERY 2800mAh==================================================Main Verdict=Pros1.Highly affordable2.Construction has a little bit of water protection3.Simplified Android experienceCons1.Subpar performance with its camera2.Choppy graphics performance3.Display has weak viewing angles4.Long recharge time with battery5.Sharpness with speaker quality==================================================Ratings-1. Battery-8.0/102. Camera-6.5/103. Performance-7/104. Display-6.5/105. Design-8/106. Software-8.5/10 (Due to Stock Android)OVERALL SCORE- ##7.5/10##==================================================//FINAL AND PERSONAL VERDICT//Lenovo clearly has some distinction with its current line of Moto-branded smartphones. The Moto G4 Play, in fact, is undeniably on one end of the spectrum, offering consumers a phone that won’t break the bank. Undoubtedly, the 8999/- full price of the phone will be seen by many as a strong candidate for those looking for a basic phone. That said, the competition in this space is hotter than ever.No doubt, the Moto G4 Play does nicely for those who aren’t looking for anything more than the most barebone smartphone experience. But when you have other phones that have a smidgen better specs, and even fingerprint sensors, it makes the Moto G4 Play seem a bit overpriced for what you are getting. We’re not saying it’s a bad phone, but rather, the competition has raised the bar from what’s expected in phones of this caliber.At Last I don't Recommend you if you are a moderate or heavy user. This phone is good for first time buyer and Basic user.############################################Other Alternatives:1. Redmi 3s2. Redmi 3s PrimeFor more details contact twitter/sumitsharma655"
 [1] "This phone definitely delivers a lot more than its asking price !I use the phone mainly for emails, social media and of course to make phone calls and it is flawless and very snappy, thanks to the pure  version of Android.The IPS display is great and very easy on the eyes unlike some of the AMOLED screens of which I'm not a big fan. Text looks great and not pixelated at all.Touch is very sensitive and has a great feel to it.Battery is more than enough to get your day covered. On moderate to heavy use it wouldn't be a problem to get it through the day.I don't use the phone for gaming and so can't comment on that. But simple gaming shouldn't be a problem.Didn't face any issue with WIFI and Bluetooth. Speed of WIFI is  good as well.And finally, I've been using the phone for a week now and absolutely no heating issues so far. The phone remains surprisingly cool even when I use it while it is charging.Edit after using for about 3 weeks now..Still agree with all the points mentioned above.Rear camera is adequate outside in day light but suffers greatly for indoor shots or less lit area. Also camera not good enough for scanning purpose to use with apps like Genius scan.GPS was having trouble finding satellites inside car. I had to put it beside the car's front glass for reception and still it was little sluhgish. My old iPhone 4s used to work great even if I had it in the front rear seat or cup holder near the gear area.But we are talking about a 9000 rupees phone with good brand value.On balance, I'm still totally satisfied with my purchase considering its snappy experience, good screen, great battery life, absolutely no heating issues and pretty quick charging.However if camera is your top most priority, then you might want to keep looking."

 [8] "First of all I don’t understand why Motorola is not launching all their G4 variants at once in India. I mean why one by one when all of them are at different price tag. Now lets move on to the topic of the post which is about the Moto G4 Play (4th Generation) pros and cons. However do note that the review points which I have mentioned below are based on facts rather than my personal taste. Reasons to Buy Moto G Play, 4th Gen (Pros):1. The display resolution is only a HD panel but because of the smaller 5 inch size the pixel density is higher than a 5.5 inch. Color representation, saturation and brightness are evenly balanced with good viewing angles.2. Its processor is powered by a 1.2 GHz Snapdragon 410 chipset which is kind of decent.3. Along with that it comes with a primary memory of 2 GB. Now compared to its counterparts its more than enough as Moto devices are completely bloatware free.4. Next Moto G4 Play pros is that for gaming the graphics is powered by Adreno 306 which runs many of the high end games smoothly.5. Consumers buy Motorola smartphones primarily for their clean software. And yes this one is absolutely clean which is almost stock Android. The version of the Marshmallow 6.0.1 which is currently the latest one.6. While many smartphones are ditching their memory card slot, this smartphone has a got dedicated one. It can be expanded up to 128 GB with the help of a microSD card.7. Another Moto G4 Play pros is the nano coating over the smartphone display provides water repellent feature. (But remember that this is not water resistant).8. The battery capacity is of 2800 mAh which is enough for a 5 inch screen smartphone to last throughout the day even for an avid user.9. For the protection of the display it comes with a Corning Gorilla 3.10. And yes it has a fast battery charging technology, not Quick Charge though but with a 10 watt rapid charger.Reasons Not to Buy Moto G Play, 4th Gen (Cons):1. The first is the quality of both the 8 megapixel primary camera and 5 megapixel secondary camera is not good in low light condition. The LED flash helps a little but not much to remove grains. The reason is because of the smaller f/2.2 focal aperture.2. Next Moto G4 Play cons is that despite being a small 5 inch smartphone it still feels bulky due to the thickness of 9.9 mm. This is too thick in today’s standard.3. At the current price tag there are dozens of smartphones that does comes with a fingerprint sensor, but this one ain’t got one.4. Another Moto G Play 4th Gen cons is that there is no dedicated navigational touch buttons below the screen. The screen is already a small one and the navigation’s are all placed on the screen itself.5. And finally the last Moto G Play (4th Gen) cons is that there is no gyroscope sensor."

 [3] "The Moto G4 Play and Moto E3 Power are currently the best offerings by the Lenovo owned Motorola. If you're not really a fan of Chinese deviceslike Redmi, Coolpad, Meizu or OnePlus, Motorola devices have really proven themselves to be quite long lasting companions.Now, within the budget segment of 10K, we've these 2 phones and without much delay I would like to review how both these phones fair against each other.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Build Quality:->-----------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play look quite similar to each other. Both feature a plastic body with a sort of textured finish. But the E3 Power houses a separate speaker grill at the bottom bezels while the G4 Play has a mono grill at the top for the earpiece and speaker. The sound output is better on E3 Power due to the extra grill.The back of E3 Power lacks a textured finish while the G4 Play has a texture design on back, making it easy to hold in hand.Screen & Display:->------------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play feature a 5\" inch 720 x 1280 pixels 294 ppi pixel density display. It's fairly bright and offers great contrast thanks to the low black levels. Sunlight legibility is also good.Both the phones have Corning Gorilla Glass 3 Protection and Nano Coating which makes them splash proof or accidental water spillings.While the Moto G4 Play has Moto Display and One Handed Mode, the E3 Power doesn't have them.Performance:->-----------------------The E3 Power runs on a MediaTek 6735P QuadCore CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1GHz and a Mali-T720 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 1.1GB to be free. Switching between apps and multi-tasking is fluid. The phone has noticeable lags on heavy usage. The device performs poorly on heavy gaming, although midrange games like Subway Surfers run well without any issues. No heating issues as well.The G4 Play runs on a Snapdragon 410 Quad Core CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1.2GHz and a Adreno 306 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 900 MB to be free. Ram management seems poor on G4 Play as compared to E3 Power as the usage seems to be more. But surprisingly the device fares better to E3 Power in terms of multi-tasking and Gaming due to a powerful CPU. Asphalt 8 runs smoothly without any issue. The device heats upto 38.C to 40.C which isn't always an issue.Storage:->---------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play come with 16GB of Internal Storage. You get upto 11GB free on E3 Power while around 10.5GB on the G4 Play. Both the phones support USB OTG.Expandable Storage:E3 Power: 32GB via MicroSD CardG4 Play: 128GB via MicroSD CardCamera:->----------------Both the E3 Power and G4 Play house a 8MP Rear and 5MP Front facing Camera. The performance is above average in daylight and proper lighting conditions. The Camera performs average in night and low light. The flash is really helpful in low light. The device runs Moto's Stock Camera app with a Shutter button. You can use the exposure mode, Panoroma, HDR or Video Modes. While the E3 Power can only record 720p videos, G4 Play can record upto 1080p videos. The Camera focusing on E3 Power is better than that of G4 Play, so is the post image processing but the shutter speed is better in G4 Play.The Selfie Camera will really delight you. You can always use a 3rd Party filter app on the both these devices to take some neat selfies.Battery:->---------------While the E3 Power comes with a 3600maH battery, the G4 Play comes with a 2800maH battery. The battery on E3 Power is nothing short to incredible and easily lasts for a day with moderate usage. and last over 1.5 days but with heavy usage lasts only upto 9 to 10 hours.. You can get screen on-time of 8 to 9 hours easily. The rapid charger bundled with the phone takes 3.5 hours to 4 hours to fully charge the device.The G4 Play lasts upto a day with moderate usage but with heavy usage lasts only upto 7 to 8 hours. The G4 Play also comes with the rapid charger and the charging takes around 3 hours.Both the phones feature a removable battery.4G Network & Jio:->-------------------------------Both Moto E3 Power and G4 Play support VoLTE (Band 40) and can be used with a Reliance Jio Sim Welcome Offer. Yes, you can dial numbers from Stock Dialer without connecting to Mobile Data. Bear in mind that the phones reach upto a temperature of 40.C when continuously on 4G.Battery Life on 4G:->-------------------------------With continuous 4G usage, the E3 Power can last for 6 to 7 hours while the G4 Play lasts upto 5 hours.Software & OS:->--------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play run of Stock Android version of Android 6.0 Marshmallow with Minor Tweaks by Motorola. Although the E3 Power is a month old, it won't get the Android Nougat 7.0 update which is a huge disappointment for budget users, while the G4 Play with 14 other devices will get Android 7.0 Nougat Update.Conclusion->--------------------The E3 Power proves to be the obvious choice if you want a device that performs better on battery life as well as the Camera. The E3 Power is available every Monday via Flash sales on Flipkart for Rs 7999.The G4 Play although has a smaller battery is a better performer with the powerful CPU and higher capacity for storage via MicroSD Card. The G4 Play will also get the Nougat Update.If you're not into heavy usage and Android Updates, the E3 Power should be your choice."
 [4] "HELLO FRIENDS MOTO G4 PLAY IS A STYLISH PHONE AND HAVING PRETTY DECENT SPECS TOO.THIS IS MY HONEST REVIEW AND MY EXPERIENCE WITH THE DEVICE.IN THE BOX1.THE G4 PLAY ITSELF2. USB CABLE3. TURBO CHARGER4. BASIC EARPHONES5. MANUALS AND WARRENTY GUIDEDESIGN AND SCREENThe Moto g4 play has a full plastic built. The back and the battery are removable where you will also find the micro SD card slot and dual 4g SIM card slot, it supports VoLTE my jio network worked on it just fine. Feels very light while holding. It doesn't have the finger print scanner. it works pretty well for both calls and media consumption. The 5 inch display is decent, it's only 720p but colours looks decent and vibrant, with decent amount of brightness, but the viewing angles are not that great the colours gets washed out in some angles. The display is not better than the Redmi note 3 or the coolpad note 5, but it gets the job done.PERFORMANCEthe Moto g4 play has the snapdragon 410 processor with the ADRENO 306 GPU and 2 GB of ram, the processor works great for day to day usage and casual gaming, it also handles heavy usage pretty well but the gaming performance is not that good, there is a lot of lagging in heavy games. The multitasking of this phone was pretty average with the 2 GB I was able to only run 4-5 apps in the background. The Moto g4 play runs on the android 6.0 marshmallow with the stock android UI on top of it, the UI is very nice it doesn't have much bloat ware right out of the box. I personally love the stock android looks, but many people don't like it much.CAMERAThe 8mp rear camera is pretty average, under natural lighting, the dynamic range is okay, with decent colour reproduction but sometimes the exposure compensation doesn't work that good, the low light performance is pretty bad, there is a lot of noise in the images. The camera does shoot videos in 1080p resolution but again the video quality is pretty average. The front facing 5mp camera is okay the images looks a bit over saturated for me but it is nice not great.BATTERYThe 2800 MAH battery is pretty average as well, you may get a day of battery life on moderate usage. But it is not good for heavy users or gamers. The g4 play does support fast charging and comes with the turbo charger, it takes around 2.5 or 3 hours to get fully charge.THE PROS1. DECENT BUILT2. DUAL SIM WITH 4G VoLTE SUPPORT3. MICRO SD CARD SLOT4. GOOD FOR DAY TO DAY MODERATE USAGE5. DECENT DISPLAY6. DECENT SPEAKERTHE CONS1. AVERAGE CAMERA2. AVERAGE BATTERY LIFE3. NOT GOOD FOR MULTITASKING OR INTENSE GAMING4. NO FINGERPRINT SCANNER5. NO GYROSCOPE MEANS NO VR SUPPORTTHE MOTO G4 PLAY IS A PRETTY AVERAGE SMART PHONE WITH AVERAGE SPECS, IT IS ONLY GOOD FOR MODERATE USERS AND THOSE WHO LOVE STOCK ANDROID EXPERIENCE, FOR PERFORMANCE WISE THE REDMI NOTE 3 PERFORMS BETTER IN PROCESSING, CAMERA, AND BATTERY PERFORMANCE. BUT YOU HAVE TO SPEND SOMEWHAT MORE MONEY……"  [5] "I bought this on September 10. Since October 17, the battery inadvertently gets heated up. This has no set pattern. Sometimes while charging sometimes while using the phone. No particular pattern. I am no gamer, so it heats up in normal usage. Writing to Lenovo customer care, directed me to Motorola Customer care. This is what they have to say:Uninstall one by one application and check with the device performance.1. Reduce the brightness to Auto or lower down the brightness levels under Settings--Display-Brightness2. Reduce the sleep timeout- under Settings--Display-Sleep-Set it to 30 sec3. Disable live wallpaper ( if any) under Settings--Display-Wallpaper4. Close all the background applications. Educate customers to close all recent applications properly.5. Turn off Wi-Fi when not required,Using camera for extended period of time leads the device to heat.6. Turn off 3G when not required7. Turn off Bluetooth when not requiredEven after following this if the device exceeds please do a factory reset. Basically don't use the phone.Samsung at one point of time wanted the Note users to charge their battery only up to 60%. Avoided Samsung to get stuck with the same issue.Anyone else facing the same issue? It  worked very well for 45 days and then the battery started heating up. Has anyone faced a similar issue?  [2] "DesignThe Moto G4 Play has a thin frame at 9.9mm and the weight is 4.83 ounces (0.31 pounds). At the top-front of the G4 Play is a front-facing speaker. And at the bottom is the micro USB charger port. The 3.5mm headphone jack is at the top of the G4 Play.On the back of the G4 Play is a plastic cover and it can be peeled from the bottom. The edges of the G4 Play are rounded, making it easier to grip in the palm of your hand. The Moto G4 is available in two colors: black and white.What features seem to be missing from the G4 Play? The G4 Play does not have a fingerprint sensor like the G4 Plus does. And the G4 Play is not as durable as devices like the Galaxy S7 and the iPhone 7 because it does not come with an IP rating. And it does not have near field communications (NFC). However, the G4 Play does have water repellent nano-coating so it is protected from splashes and rain."

 [7] "The Moto G4 Play and Moto E3 Power are currently the best offerings by the Lenovo owned Motorola. If you're not really a fan of Chinese deviceslike Redmi, Coolpad, Meizu or OnePlus, Motorola devices have really proven themselves to be quite long lasting companions.Now, within the budget segment of 10K, we've these 2 phones and without much delay I would like to review how both these phones fair against each other.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Build Quality:->-----------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play look quite similar to each other. Both feature a plastic body with a sort of textured finish. But the E3 Power houses a separate speaker grill at the bottom bezels while the G4 Play has a mono grill at the top for the earpiece and speaker. The sound output is better on E3 Power due to the extra grill.The back of E3 Power lacks a textured finish while the G4 Play has a texture design on back, making it easy to hold in hand.Screen & Display:->------------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play feature a 5\" inch 720 x 1280 pixels 294 ppi pixel density display. It's fairly bright and offers great contrast thanks to the low black levels. Sunlight legibility is also good.Both the phones have Corning Gorilla Glass 3 Protection and Nano Coating which makes them splash proof or accidental water spillings.While the Moto G4 Play has Moto Display and One Handed Mode, the E3 Power doesn't have them.Performance:->-----------------------The E3 Power runs on a MediaTek 6735P QuadCore CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1GHz and a Mali-T720 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 1.1GB to be free. Switching between apps and multi-tasking is fluid. The phone has noticeable lags on heavy usage. The device performs poorly on heavy gaming, although midrange games like Subway Surfers run well without any issues. No heating issues as well.The G4 Play runs on a Snapdragon 410 Quad Core CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1.2GHz and a Adreno 306 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 900 MB to be free. Ram management seems poor on G4 Play as compared to E3 Power as the usage seems to be more. But surprisingly the device fares better to E3 Power in terms of multi-tasking and Gaming due to a powerful CPU. Asphalt 8 runs smoothly without any issue. The device heats upto 38.C to 40.C which isn't always an issue.Storage:->---------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play come with 16GB of Internal Storage. You get upto 11GB free on E3 Power while around 10.5GB on the G4 Play. Both the phones support USB OTG.Expandable Storage:E3 Power: 32GB via MicroSD CardG4 Play: 128GB via MicroSD CardCamera:->----------------Both the E3 Power and G4 Play house a 8MP Rear and 5MP Front facing Camera. The performance is above average in daylight and proper lighting conditions. The Camera performs average in night and low light. The flash is really helpful in low light. The device runs Moto's Stock Camera app with a Shutter button. You can use the exposure mode, Panoroma, HDR or Video Modes. While the E3 Power can only record 720p videos, G4 Play can record upto 1080p videos. The Camera focusing on E3 Power is better than that of G4 Play, so is the post image processing but the shutter speed is better in G4 Play.The Selfie Camera will really delight you. You can always use a 3rd Party filter app on the both these devices to take some neat selfies.Battery:->---------------While the E3 Power comes with a 3600maH battery, the G4 Play comes with a 2800maH battery. The battery on E3 Power is nothing short to incredible and easily lasts for a day with moderate usage. and last over 1.5 days but with heavy usage lasts only upto 9 to 10 hours.. You can get screen on-time of 8 to 9 hours easily. The rapid charger bundled with the phone takes 3.5 hours to 4 hours to fully charge the device.The G4 Play lasts upto a day with moderate usage but with heavy usage lasts only upto 7 to 8 hours. The G4 Play also comes with the rapid charger and the charging takes around 3 hours.Both the phones feature a removable battery.4G Network & Jio:->-------------------------------Both Moto E3 Power and G4 Play support VoLTE (Band 40) and can be used with a Reliance Jio Sim Welcome Offer. Yes, you can dial numbers from Stock Dialer without connecting to Mobile Data. Bear in mind that the phones reach upto a temperature of 40.C when continuously on 4G.Battery Life on 4G:->-------------------------------With continuous 4G usage, the E3 Power can last for 6 to 7 hours while the G4 Play lasts upto 5 hours.Software & OS:->--------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play run of Stock Android version of Android 6.0 Marshmallow with Minor Tweaks by Motorola. Although the E3 Power is a month old, it won't get the Android Nougat 7.0 update which is a huge disappointment for budget users, while the G4 Play with 14 other devices will get Android 7.0 Nougat Update.Conclusion->--------------------The E3 Power proves to be the obvious choice if you want a device that performs better on battery life as well as the Camera. The E3 Power is available every Monday via Flash sales on Flipkart for Rs 7999.The G4 Play although has a smaller battery is a better performer with the powerful CPU and higher capacity for storage via MicroSD Card. The G4 Play will also get the Nougat Update.If you're not into heavy usage and Android Updates, the E3 Power should be your choice"

 [1] "I purchased this phone on 7th sept received on 8th sept. Thanx to amazon delivery.Its really a good phone under 10k. It has vey nice 5 inch display with IPS technology which has pixel density of 294.Good camera quality.Battery is 2800 mah which is enough for average use.I don't play games on this device but tested for its performance,  games were running fine. It has minor lags while playing hd games(I played nova 3 freedom edition). Also device get heated up for continuous playing for approx 15 mins & reduced battery by 30%. Also played CoC for half an hour but no significant battery drain observed(also device heated up a bit).It comes with 10w charger which charges device in 15mins(they say so, but actually fast charge work upto 70% after that battery charge on normal speed). Also no significant draining of battery while connected to wifi(I'm connected to wifi from 10am where charging was 93% and now 12.30 pm charging is 83%).It has pure android ui, no bloatwares(extra unwanted apps). Also it is light in weight.conclusion:-It is average phone with some good features..."

 [2] "I had Motorola walkie talkies as a child and am well aware that this is a super brand. I was looking at an affordable model for some time and this seemed to fit the bill. However, despite a good design and fast processor, the settings are cumbersome and not user friendly. With great difficulty I was able to set the APN settings of my 4G carrier Reliance and had to extensively manipulate the options to get at it (It requires lots of fiddling with permissions which are hard to find). I had to search the online help forums and finally got to set it. NOW, came the big NEGATIVE. My previous phones were seamlessly coupling with my JVC car audio system and I could hear phone calls and retrieve the phonebook on the LCD display. Moto G Play although connecting via bluetooth did not elicit any response on the car system. neither could I make or receive calls (which I always do by stopping the car - NEVER while driving), nor could I get the phonebook on my otherwise latest modern double DIN JVC system. Extensive search on the internet for 2 days (48 hours yielded no results). I searched forums and helplines with the keywords - Moto G Play/bluetooth connectivity/ marshmallow Android system.bluetooth, etc. NO RESULT. The searches led to American Moto help forums. I searched for Moto India Helpline: Found it, called, no response - the line was dead. I searched for the regional Moto landline number for North India in Chandigarh: The landline number which I found when dialed elicited the response: \"This Number Does Not Exist\" tried again by upgrading the firmware of my JVC system: No result. FINALLY, I took out my SIMS and went back to my old faithful LTE smartphone. My faith in Motorola stands shattered."

Yes it has an old one, but it shouldn't matter since the performance is smooth and it plays GTA san Andreas on med setting very well. If you owned a high end phone or a tablet like me(i own an iPad air 2) you will immediately notice the difference in performance. Anyways this is one of the smoothest UI you will get in any phone below 10k . There was one thing which is disappointing, the audio output is less when compared to Xiaomi(or apple ) . If you have high end headphones with high resistance, you might have to use an amp. One last thing , this phone doesn't come with jio sim. It does support it,though. Also one let down is that when you Chromecast the screen , the quality is poor ( not more than 480p) and there is a significant drop in the performance. Youtube videos play seamlessly in 1080(on chromecast)"

[10] "Motorola launched this device a few days back and it is mainly aimed at people who love to enjoy entertainment on their handheld device.The phone features some incredible features and some drawbacks. Let us talk about the various aspects of this device.DISPLAY:5in display is just the perfect size in my opinion. 720p HD is decent for viewing videos but is not adequate for immersive gaming experience. During the review, the colors produced decent and the viewing angles were not that great. Gorilla glass 3 provides additional security as I survived a couple of drops from 3-4 feet without damaging the screen.BATTERY:Motorola claims that this battery lasts for a day with moderate usage but that is not the case. I usually end up charging this phone thrice a day with moderate-heavy usage with about 30 mins of gaming. The charging is quite fast as compared to its competitors. The phone did heat up a bit while charging.SOFTWARE:Motorola is one of those companies which are still producing devices with almost no bloat. The company has tried to provide users with a stock android experience in this device. The device has voLTE compability and worked well with my JIO 4G sim during the test period.INTERNAL:The phone is powered by a snapdragon 410 processor which is quite old. 2GB of RAM is not adequate as I found lagging issues on this device. The phone cannot even handle 15 light apps running in the background.CAMERA:Low- light performance is not that great. The photos are of decent quality and the HDR mode works just fine. Motorola need to work on its software department as the camera app needs to refined.Verdict: The phone feels quiet cheap in the hand with its plastic build. The buttons are clicky and provide a nice feedback. The speakers are average and the display is a bit outdated. But considering the price of this device, It has a lot of positives including water resistance and fast charging. I would highly consider other competitors such as coolpad note 3 plus and Le 1s eco,Le2. The phone is a good buy for people who wish to have a nice and affordable smartphone for light use."

 [6] "Before i start let me tell you that i really hate brands like Xiaomi, Coolpad, Oppo etc.Not that there is anything wrong with them, it's just a matter of personal opinion.In comparison with the Redmi 3S prime and similary priced phones , the G4 play is on the lower end of the specs sheet.But that certainly does not mean it is less efficient or productive in any way.As a matter of fact, the stock Android and brilliant optimisation makes up for it.I have been using this phone for over a month now and these are the pros and cons :Pros:1.Amazing battery life.on paper 2800 mAH might not seem to be big, but the screen size, resolution and software tweaks/doze mode increases the battery life to a very good extent.2.The screen is pretty good for this price range.The viewing angles are good, colour reproduction is good and the 293 ppi is apt for a 5 inch screen.(1080p would have drained battery faster, been more tasking on the processor and is really an overkill for a 5 inch display)3.Camera: This is one of the best camera I've seen in a phone in the below 10K price range.The daylight photos are amazing.But the night-time photos are a bit grainy, but that can be fixed with filters and a bit editing.The front Camera too does not fail to impress.4.Software updates is the main reason i chose this phone over the e3 power as this will be getting the Nougat 7.0 update in December.5.Fast charging : This goes from 10-60 in about 30mins , and it takes another 45 mins to reach 100.Most of us really need only  60% for everyday use, so that shouldn't be a problem.Also Doze mode is very good at minimising power usage while the phone is not in use.Heavy users can charge it early in the morning in case they need the 100%.Cons:1.The processor: the Adreno 410 is a famous processor , well known for being in almost all budget phones since 2013 ,But this is 2016 . The processor is a bit outdated and the gpu can handle most games expect for very intensive games like Nova 3.But come on, for 8999 you can't expect to see an Adreno 617 or an 800 :).Yet again people might say similarly priced Redmi 3S prime has better specs, but guess what, their UI is crap and their hardware isn't well optimised.At the end of the day, it is your opinion, playing a bit intensive game, or having a smooth experience.Don't get me wrong here, apart from stuttering while running intensive games, there is nothing else it complain about it.Normal to medium- heavy ish games run real fine and daily usage/multitasking happens without a hiccup.2.Heating is an unavoidable factor but i still wished they looked into this a little.The phone heats when playing continuously or while charging (Fast charger, duh!)3.Bezel: I just wish that the screen to body ratio would have  been increased a little bit in this as the bottom looks a bit bare without the fingerprint.4.No fingerprint sensor: Yes , most phones in this  range have one, but the price is low so i think it is justified.5.No gyroscope: for people who don't need this, this should been be a problem, but some moto actions like chop twice for flashlight and some games might need it.Note that Pokémon go requires a gyroscope for AR, but if it's turned off, the app will work just fine.Extra Points:The moto G4 Play gets extra marks for making the battery removable and for incorporting the moto display feature into this.It also is splash resistant, not waterproof.( Isn't a major issue, even it's big brother the G4 plus and the 35K moto Z lack waterproofing)Also for clarification, even though its not mentioned anywhere, just like the moto G4 and G4 plus , the G4 play also has Gorilla Glass 3.Verdict: For Medium - heavy users on a tight budget, or as a secondary phone or as a temporary replacement,the Moto G4 Play is the best phone in the market right now.My Rating : 8.9/10"  [8] "HELLOThe Moto G4 Play and Moto E3 Power are currently the best offerings by the Lenovo owned Motorola. If you're not really a fan of Chinese deviceslike Redmi, Coolpad, Meizu or OnePlus, Motorola devices have really proven themselves to be quite long lasting companions.Now, within the budget segment of 10K, we've these 2 phones and without much delay I would like to review how both these phones fair against each other.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Build Quality:->-----------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play look quite similar to each other. Both feature a plastic body with a sort of textured finish. But the E3 Power houses a separate speaker grill at the bottom bezels while the G4 Play has a mono grill at the top for the earpiece and speaker. The sound output is better on E3 Power due to the extra grill.The back of E3 Power lacks a textured finish while the G4 Play has a texture design on back, making it easy to hold in hand.Screen & Display:->------------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play feature a 5\" inch 720 x 1280 pixels 294 ppi pixel density display. It's fairly bright and offers great contrast thanks to the low black levels. Sunlight legibility is also good.Both the phones have Corning Gorilla Glass 3 Protection and Nano Coating which makes them splash proof or accidental water spillings.While the Moto G4 Play has Moto Display and One Handed Mode, the E3 Power doesn't have them.Performance:->-----------------------The E3 Power runs on a MediaTek 6735P QuadCore CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1GHz and a Mali-T720 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 1.1GB to be free. Switching between apps and multi-tasking is fluid. The phone has noticeable lags on heavy usage. The device performs poorly on heavy gaming, although midrange games like Subway Surfers run well without any issues. No heating issues as well.The G4 Play runs on a Snapdragon 410 Quad Core CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1.2GHz and a Adreno 306 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 900 MB to be free. Ram management seems poor on G4 Play as compared to E3 Power as the usage seems to be more. But surprisingly the device fares better to E3 Power in terms of multi-tasking and Gaming due to a powerful CPU. Asphalt 8 runs smoothly without any issue. The device heats upto 38.C to 40.C which isn't always an issue.Storage:->---------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play come with 16GB of Internal Storage. You get upto 11GB free on E3 Power while around 10.5GB on the G4 Play. Both the phones support USB OTG.Expandable Storage:E3 Power: 32GB via MicroSD CardG4 Play: 128GB via MicroSD CardCamera:->----------------Both the E3 Power and G4 Play house a 8MP Rear and 5MP Front facing Camera. The performance is above average in daylight and proper lighting conditions. The Camera performs average in night and low light. The flash is really helpful in low light. The device runs Moto's Stock Camera app with a Shutter button. You can use the exposure mode, Panoroma, HDR or Video Modes. While the E3 Power can only record 720p videos, G4 Play can record upto 1080p videos. The Camera focusing on E3 Power is better than that of G4 Play, so is the post image processing but the shutter speed is better in G4 Play.The Selfie Camera will really delight you. You can always use a 3rd Party filter app on the both these devices to take some neat selfies.Battery:->---------------While the E3 Power comes with a 3600maH battery, the G4 Play comes with a 2800maH battery. The battery on E3 Power is nothing short to incredible and easily lasts for a day with moderate usage. and last over 1.5 days but with heavy usage lasts only upto 9 to 10 hours.. You can get screen on-time of 8 to 9 hours easily. The rapid charger bundled with the phone takes 3.5 hours to 4 hours to fully charge the device.The G4 Play lasts upto a day with moderate usage but with heavy usage lasts only upto 7 to 8 hours. The G4 Play also comes with the rapid charger and the charging takes around 3 hours.Both the phones feature a removable battery.4G Network & Jio:->-------------------------------Both Moto E3 Power and G4 Play support VoLTE (Band 40) and can be used with a Reliance Jio Sim Welcome Offer. Yes, you can dial numbers from Stock Dialer without connecting to Mobile Data. Bear in mind that the phones reach upto a temperature of 40.C when continuously on 4G.Battery Life on 4G:->-------------------------------With continuous 4G usage, the E3 Power can last for 6 to 7 hours while the G4 Play lasts upto 5 hours.Software & OS:->--------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play run of Stock Android version of Android 6.0 Marshmallow with Minor Tweaks by Motorola. Although the E3 Power is a month old, it won't get the Android Nougat 7.0 update which is a huge disappointment for budget users, while the G4 Play with 14 other devices will get Android 7.0 Nougat Update.Conclusion->--------------------The E3 Power proves to be the obvious choice if you want a device that performs better on battery life as well as the Camera. The E3 Power is available every Monday via Flash sales on Flipkart for Rs 7999.The G4 Play although has a smaller battery is a better performer with the powerful CPU and higher capacity for storage via MicroSD Card. The G4 Play will also get the Nougat Update.If you're not into heavy usage and Android Updates, the E3 Power should be your choice.PLEASE LIKE MY REVIEW"
 [9] "Motorola Moto G4 Play smartphone was launched in May 2016. The phone comes with a 5.00-inch touchscreen display with a resolution of 720 pixels by 1280 pixels at a PPI of 294 pixels per inch.The Motorola Moto G4 Play is powered by 1.2GHz quad-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 410 processor and it comes with 2GB of RAM. The phone packs 16GB of internal storage that can be expanded up to 128GB via a microSD card. As far as the cameras are concerned, the Motorola Moto G4 Play packs a 8-megapixel primary camera on the rear and a 5-megapixel front shooter for selfies.The Motorola Moto G4 Play runs Android 6.0.1 and is powered by a 2800mAh non removable battery. It measures 144.40 x 72.00 x 9.90 (height x width x thickness) and weighs 137.00 grams.The Motorola Moto G4 Play is a dual SIM (GSM and GSM) smartphone that accepts two Micro-SIM. Connectivity options include Wi-Fi, GPS, Bluetooth, FM, 3G, 4G (with support for Band 40 used by some LTE networks in India). Sensors on the phone include Proximity sensor, Ambient light sensor, Accelerometer, and Gyroscope."  [5] "I've used many motorola Android devices so far, and I recently bought moto g play. I don't want to tell all those specification related techie things like few others do. I'm writing this as a normal person who have averge use of phone a day.This is good phone with a day long battery life. Say you leave home with the home full charged, you wont need to charge the phone untill you reach back your home.  8 to 11 hours of battery life for an average user with calling and internet.Camera is good  for average photography, both front and rear camera. Instant beautification option while taking selfie is nice.Light weigted phone. Handy. Display is good. Sound clarity is fine. Good signal reception. User storage phone memory is 11gb, good enough for an average user.Lag less operating system. Haven't faced any heating issues for normal usage.Quick charging is wonderfull. It will quick charge the phone till 60% and thereafter it reduces the speed of chaging to normal, as a safe measure for the battery life.Good choice for those who are looking for a phone in the budget category, especially for their parents and siblings."  [6] "First of ,thanks to Amazon for delivering the product real quick.For first impression ,I would say that it looks far better than I thought.The side aluminium/metal frame looks very premium.Also the device feels very lightweight in hands.The battery here is removable ,unlike old Moto devices.I am totally satisfied with the build quality and overall finishing.A very well made product.INBOX CONTENTS:1-Handset2-Battery3-Ton of manual and user guide4-Normal old school earphones5-Fast charger and USB cable----------------------------------------------NOW COMING TO MY REVIEW-----------------------------------------------#=THE BUILD QUALITY as I said is really good, well its Motorola!.The power button and the volume control button uses metallic material with good grip.Unlike the cheep plastic ones.Power button is above the volume button ,which may not be that handy for some users.But don't worry ,you will get used to it.Anyway the buttons provide excellent feedback.The navigation buttons are on-screen type and lacks hardware keys.Display is quite bright and clear.Because its 5 inch a HD screen is enough.You would hardly notice any pixelation ,unless you look really close.#=UI AND PERFORMANCE - As usual with every moto device ,The moto G play also comes with stock android.Which is basically the selling point of moto devices. Because you get fast OS updates.Even though ,the device is shipped with Marshmallow.It will get the Nougat update real soon.It is equipped with snapdragon 410 which is quite outdated now and fits in low end category.Despite that the UI experience is very smooth in moto g play.Well I remember my old grand prime had the same chipset.At that time it use to run most of the games with ease.I installed quite a few basic games in Gplay and found it is still capable of running some decent graphics rich games.The animations were at 1X when got it,I turned it down to 0.5X using developer options and now it seems much faster and fluid.#CAMERA is Okey ,I never expected it to perform exceptional with camera because it comes with a low end sensor.But anyways it is capable of taking some decent shots which are very similar to on5 pro and better than K5 plus.The front snapper is also decent and snaps some bright selfies.Overall I think the camera is decent for the asking price.Note:Low light performance is below average.#BATTERY LIFE It comes with 2800mah battery which is quite enough because there is nothing that will consume too much battery.So i hope it will last for a full working day.After using it for one day ,I think I got more than 6 hours of On screen time because today is the first day So,I was checking out all the features.Anyway I will comment more about the battery life after 2-3 days.#NETWORK I mainly bought it to use JIO 4G ,because this phone supports true 4G.Yes you can make VoLTE calls and use 4G data.The speed it offers is really good.Totally satisfied with my purchase.Conclusion----------------This is for those people who need good battery life ,decent performance for basic day to day tasks ,good call quality and ofcourse a phone with good build quality and after sales support.The camera is enough for basic picture snapping.Overall I am really satisfied with my purchase.This phone really exceeded my expectations.Thanks I hope you like my review.If you have any further queries then feel free to comment down below.Thank you,Best Regards;Yousuf Ali Khan"
 [7] "I bought this phone on 6th sep and received it on 8th Sep 2016.Packing: Packing was really bad, but delivery was quick.Built: Phone's built is not very impressive, Slightly thicker body. The back cover is really low quality. It feels like it will melt during summer due to heat. The button shows good amount of feedback that is a good thing. Corning gorilla glass, water repellent coating make it reliable.Camera: Rear camera (8 mp LED Flash) and Front Camera (5 mp) shows very good color reproduction in low light as well as artificial lights. Negative point is that the front camera doesn't have led flash. There are editing and beautification options too. There is a secondary mic for noise cancellation.Display: 720 p hd display with CG glass. Short cut option for one handed operation available. Good viewing angles, edges are smooth and sharp. Sun readability not upto the mark.Processer : Snapdragon 410 processor at a price point of 8999 ' can be said BETTER because if we would have had 615 octa core processor it could have caused heating issues. Therefore, given processor can be said better at this price point for this phone.Android versions: Marshmallows 6.0 good system with no bloat wares is exceptionally great thing about this phone.File manager: A file manager app is given instead of a gallery. Not very impressive!In short, the gallery is summarised in file manager so that we are able to access photos, videos, word, PDF, zip files. It is good thing to get all things at one place.Sound: Sound quality is better not best with speaker as well as headphones given. You need to buy best quality head phones which is already mentioned in the offers for buyersUI: stock android UI is lag free , but RAM management is not as good as compared to Redmi 3s prime. If you open up 10-15 apps simultaneously, while switching to the first open app it starts to reload....Gaming: gaming is average, some frames drops at times while playing hd games. If you are a Gamer consider buying high end phones Better GPU with all sensors like gyro, compass and ram over 4 gb with 820 snapdragon processor.Continued....Jio sim review:I found calls being made very easily with Jio 4g sim. No need to install any voice calling app. Data connectivity is also good not better since Jio speed reduces. Calls quality is better with Jio. But other operators does not provide sufficient POI (point of interconnect) to Jio . This has been the major problem. Also to let you know that Jio calls are made through data connections it further deteriorates the situation considering the fact that other operators are not provide support to Jio.To conclude, I would say that calls are better not best using Jio. Internet quality from Jio would be rated as 3½ stars"

 [4] "The Moto G4 Play and Moto E3 Power are currently the best offerings by the Lenovo owned Motorola. If you're not really a fan of Chinese deviceslike Redmi, Coolpad, Meizu or OnePlus, Motorola devices have really proven themselves to be quite long lasting companions.Now, within the budget segment of 10K, we've these 2 phones and without much delay I would like to review how both these phones fair against each other.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Build Quality:->-----------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play look quite similar to each other. Both feature a plastic body with a sort of textured finish. But the E3 Power houses a separate speaker grill at the bottom bezels while the G4 Play has a mono grill at the top for the earpiece and speaker. The sound output is better on E3 Power due to the extra grill.The back of E3 Power lacks a textured finish while the G4 Play has a texture design on back, making it easy to hold in hand.Screen & Display:->------------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play feature a 5\" inch 720 x 1280 pixels 294 ppi pixel density display. It's fairly bright and offers great contrast thanks to the low black levels. Sunlight legibility is also good.Both the phones have Corning Gorilla Glass 3 Protection and Nano Coating which makes them splash proof or accidental water spillings.While the Moto G4 Play has Moto Display and One Handed Mode, the E3 Power doesn't have them.Performance:->-----------------------The E3 Power runs on a MediaTek 6735P QuadCore CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1GHz and a Mali-T720 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 1.1GB to be free. Switching between apps and multi-tasking is fluid. The phone has noticeable lags on heavy usage. The device performs poorly on heavy gaming, although midrange games like Subway Surfers run well without any issues. No heating issues as well.The G4 Play runs on a Snapdragon 410 Quad Core CPU, which houses four Cortex-A53s clocked at 1.2GHz and a Adreno 306 GPU. You get 2GB of Ram. On the first boot you'll find around 900 MB to be free. Ram management seems poor on G4 Play as compared to E3 Power as the usage seems to be more. But surprisingly the device fares better to E3 Power in terms of multi-tasking and Gaming due to a powerful CPU. Asphalt 8 runs smoothly without any issue. The device heats upto 38.C to 40.C which isn't always an issue.Storage:->---------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play come with 16GB of Internal Storage. You get upto 11GB free on E3 Power while around 10.5GB on the G4 Play. Both the phones support USB OTG.Expandable Storage:E3 Power: 32GB via MicroSD CardG4 Play: 128GB via MicroSD CardCamera:->----------------Both the E3 Power and G4 Play house a 8MP Rear and 5MP Front facing Camera. The performance is above average in daylight and proper lighting conditions. The Camera performs average in night and low light. The flash is really helpful in low light. The device runs Moto's Stock Camera app with a Shutter button. You can use the exposure mode, Panoroma, HDR or Video Modes. While the E3 Power can only record 720p videos, G4 Play can record upto 1080p videos. The Camera focusing on E3 Power is better than that of G4 Play, so is the post image processing but the shutter speed is better in G4 Play.The Selfie Camera will really delight you. You can always use a 3rd Party filter app on the both these devices to take some neat selfies.Battery:->---------------While the E3 Power comes with a 3600maH battery, the G4 Play comes with a 2800maH battery. The battery on E3 Power is nothing short to incredible and easily lasts for a day with moderate usage. and last over 1.5 days but with heavy usage lasts only upto 9 to 10 hours.. You can get screen on-time of 8 to 9 hours easily. The rapid charger bundled with the phone takes 3.5 hours to 4 hours to fully charge the device.The G4 Play lasts upto a day with moderate usage but with heavy usage lasts only upto 7 to 8 hours. The G4 Play also comes with the rapid charger and the charging takes around 3 hours.Both the phones feature a removable battery.4G Network & Jio:->-------------------------------Both Moto E3 Power and G4 Play support VoLTE (Band 40) and can be used with a Reliance Jio Sim Welcome Offer. Yes, you can dial numbers from Stock Dialer without connecting to Mobile Data. Bear in mind that the phones reach upto a temperature of 40.C when continuously on 4G.Battery Life on 4G:->-------------------------------With continuous 4G usage, the E3 Power can last for 6 to 7 hours while the G4 Play lasts upto 5 hours.Software & OS:->--------------------------Both the Moto E3 Power and G4 Play run of Stock Android version of Android 6.0 Marshmallow with Minor Tweaks by Motorola. Although the E3 Power is a month old, it won't get the Android Nougat 7.0 update which is a huge disappointment for budget users, while the G4 Play with 14 other devices will get Android 7.0 Nougat Update.Conclusion->--------------------The E3 Power proves to be the obvious choice if you want a device that performs better on battery life as well as the Camera. The E3 Power is available every Monday via Flash sales on Flipkart for Rs 7999.The G4 Play although has a smaller battery is a better performer with the powerful CPU and higher capacity for storage via MicroSD Card. The G4 Play will also get the Nougat Update.If you're not into heavy usage and Android Updates, the E3 Power should be your choice."

 [2] "I'll keep it unbiased though I'm a huge Moto fan. Firstly the build quality is fantastic and it is a beauty to see. Secondly the camera, which was a bit of a surprise. The 5 MP camera works superb and will aptly take care of your selfie needs while the rear camera does not quite reach its standard as the pictures tend to be grainy. Then coming to the specs, they are adequate to get your daily jobs done and would qualify as mid-range. 16 GB storage and 2 GB of RAM is enough for almost everyone. Now comes the software part which is basically the reason why I love Moto. The software is stock Android Marshmallow with minimal bloatware and it has been expertly optimised to make you fall in love with the phone each time you interact with it. The only con that I could find is the price which should have been ₹ 8000 at most to make it more competitive. Finally I would say, this phone is perfect for daily use and much more. Go for it if you would choose elegance and quality  over a heavier spec sheet."

 [7] "PROS:1. The display resolution is only a HD panel but because of the smaller 5 inch size the pixel density is higher than a 5.5 inch. Color representation, saturation and brightness are evenly balanced with good viewing angles.2. Its processor is powered by a 1.2 GHz Snapdragon 410 chipset which is kind of decent.3. Along with that it comes with a primary memory of 2 GB. Now compared to its counterparts its more than enough as Moto devices are completely bloatware free.4. Next Moto G4 Play pros is that for gaming the graphics is powered by Adreno 306 which runs many of the high end games smoothly.5. Consumers buy Motorola smartphones primarily for their clean software. And yes this one is absolutely clean which is almost stock Android. The version of the Marshmallow 6.0.1 which is currently the latest one.6. While many smartphones are ditching their memory card slot, this smartphone has a got dedicated one. It can be expanded up to 128 GB with the help of a microSD card.7. Another Moto G4 Play pros is the nano coating over the smartphone display provides water repellent feature. (But remember that this is not water resistant).8. The battery capacity is of 2800 mAh which is enough for a 5 inch screen smartphone to last throughout the day even for an avid user.9. For the protection of the display it comes with a Corning Gorilla 3.10. And yes it has a fast battery charging technology, not Quick Charge though but with a 10 watt rapid charger.**************************************************************CONS:1. The first is the quality of both the 8 megapixel primary camera and 5 megapixel secondary camera is not good in low light condition. The LED flash helps a little but not much to remove grains. The reason is because of the smaller f/2.2 focal aperture.2. Next Moto G4 Play cons is that despite being a small 5 inch smartphone it still feels bulky due to the thickness of 9.9 mm. This is too thick in today’s standard.3. At the current price tag there are dozens of smartphones that does comes with a fingerprint sensor, but this one ain’t got one.4. Another Moto G Play 4th Gen cons is that there is no dedicated navigational touch buttons below the screen. The screen is already a small one and the navigation’s are all placed on the screen itself.5. And finally the last Moto G Play (4th Gen) cons is that there is no gyroscope sensor.*******************************************Good but nothing to impress. But in case if you are looking for a better alternative smartphone that removes some of the cons, then this is the one.THANKYOU."

 [8] "This was my first Moto phone. Coming to the experience:Pros:It has a decent build qualityGood displayGrippy backWater and dust resistantButtery smooth performance.Cons:Camera produces lots of noise in daylight, while in low light, especially in night, the camera does poor. Flash is also not as expected.Battery: The phone has a battery of 2450mah which is really a less productive battery for this huge 5\" display phone. With average usage, the battery did almost 8 hrs while some devices in this range last for 15 to 18 hrs.Conclusion: Overall a good device with decent performance but if you are a camera crazy; this is not the device for you. Rather, you can go for Samsung On5 pro which offers a better camera and powerpacked batter of 2600mah which offers a talktime of almost 14hrs with above average use and with power saving mode, it lasts for even 20."

 [2] "I have never had such a bad experience with Amazon or Motorola before. This is my second Moto phone from Amazon and I ordered it blindly because of faith in the companies. I have been extremely disappointed. Not only does the device not function properly, I have received very poor response when I complained about it. Most of the time the phone just drops calls. Additionally, when calls are made through this phone, nobody can hear my voice. WhatsApp calls work but not normal calls. Reception is terrible. 7 out of 10 times my calls don't go through or people can't hear me. The smart check app only checks for audio and microphone, which work fine anyway. It's the phone's reception capacity that's faulty. There is no check for that. I have been complaining about the issue since 4 days and I was informed that a technician would come and check the device. But the person called once and never showed up. When you died 9000 bucks on a product, you expect to be treated better. Worse, as a Motorola customer my faith in the brand has been lost."

 [5] "Using this phone from last week.CPU: Qualcomm Snapdragon 410 64 bit. Though the cpu is quite old but still it is being widely used in many smartphones and has enough power to carry daily task efficiently. there are chances that this device soon will be upgraded to Android 7 Nougat. It also VoLTE which means reliance Jio sim is fully supported.O.S : It is Android 6.0.1 Marshmallow. It is stock android means no preloaded apps and bloatwares. No lag and gaming experience is also very smooth.Memory: Inbuilt memory is 16 gb(Usable is approx. 12 gb) and further expandable to 128 gb via micro sd card. But i didn't find any settings where inbuilt apps are being moved to sd card or default storage path can be selected as sd card.RAM: 2 GB more than enough for day to day task.Display: It is 5\" IPS LCD display. The display quality is simply superb and it is crystal clear.Also there is glance screen but at very short period of time and you can see the messages on screen and clock even the screen is locked.Battery : Battery is 2800 mAh and it almost takes 2 hrs thanks for the 10w 2A rapid charger. Battery backup is really good even if you play heavy games or watch videos on youtube still gives one day battery backup.SIM slot : It is dual sim micro sim type and both sims supports 4G LTE. I placed my airtel 4G sim in both slots and 4G works perfectly. Also sd card is located above sim 1 slot and it is independent so there is no hybrid sim type.Also this phone also supports Full USB OTG. Call clarity is clear and there is no drop of signal or no network connectivity issues. Headphone experince is beastly but i suggest using 3rd party earphones such as Skullcandy OR JBL. Overall it is a budget android phone with clutter free android marshmallow which is fresh experience. This is my first moto smartphone and i am just enjoying it."
 [6] "I had Motorola walkie talkies as a child and am well aware that this is a super brand. I was looking at an affordable model for some time and this seemed to fit the bill. However, despite a good design and fast processor, the settings are cumbersome and not user friendly. With great difficulty I was able to set the APN settings of my 4G carrier Reliance and had to extensively manipulate the options to get at it (It requires lots of fiddling with permissions which are hard to find). I had to search the online help forums and finally got to set it. NOW, came the big NEGATIVE. My previous phones were seamlessly coupling with my JVC car audio system and I could hear phone calls and retrieve the phonebook on the LCD display. Moto G Play although connecting via bluetooth did not elicit any response on the car system. neither could I make or receive calls (which I always do by stopping the car - NEVER while driving), nor could I get the phonebook on my otherwise latest modern double DIN JVC system. Extensive search on the internet for 2 days (48 hours yielded no results). I searched forums and helplines with the keywords - Moto G Play/bluetooth connectivity/ marshmallow Android system.bluetooth, etc. NO RESULT. The searches led to American Moto help forums. I searched for Moto India Helpline: Found it, called, no response - the line was dead. I searched for the regional Moto landline number for North India in Chandigarh: The landline number which I found when dialed elicited the response: \"This Number Does Not Exist\" tried again by upgrading the firmware of my JVC system: No result. FINALLY, I took out my SIMS and went back to my old faithful LTE smartphone. My faith in Motorola stands shattered."

 [6] "The latest in Lenovo’s Moto G collection of devices is the “Play” of the G4 (2016) generation. This device looks and feels extremely similar to its closest relatives, the Moto G4 and the Moto G4 Plus. The Moto G4 Play has a Qualcomm Snapdragon 410 (MSM8916) processor inside it with 4x Cortex-A53 1.4GHz CPU and an Adreno 306 GPU. With that is 2GB of LPDDR3 RAM and a replaceable 2800mAh battery.Battery life is good – a day of average use should be easy for most users – and a replaceable battery means that switching out for a second pack could make for a long trip without charging. Inside the Moto G4 Play is 16GB of internal storage – which I’ve mentioned as a “con” above. While a smartphone released in 2016 should, by all means, have at least twice that amount of internal storage, this Moto G4 Plus does, on the other hand, have a microSD card slot for storage expansion.The display on this device is 5.0-inches (a half-inch smaller than the Moto G4 and Plus), with 1280 x 720 pixels across it. This display works with IPS LCD technology and is decent. Inside the Moto G4 Play is 16GB of internal storage. The display on this device is 5.0-inches (a half-inch smaller than the Moto G4 and Plus), with 1280 x 720 pixels across it. This display works with IPS LCD technology and is decent.Below is a gallery of photos of the Moto G4 Play as captured outside on a cloudy day in the shade of a large building. It’s not direct sunlight, but it does show how well the display shows in an environment other than the deep dark of indoors.This device is lighter than its G4 friends at 137 grams instead of 155 grams, and comes in at a slightly smaller overall size as well at 144.4 x 72.0 x 8.95 mm (instead of the G4’s 153.0 x 76.6 x 9.8 mm).Where the real descent in quality comes is the camera. Both the front and the back camera are OK::::::::::::::::::::::::IF YOU LIKED MY REVIEW GUYS PLEASE HIT THAT HELPFUL BUTTON THERE YOUR ONE HELPFUL BUTTON HELPS A LOT::::::::::::::::::::::::"

                                                                                                                                                                                     
 [5] "The Moto G has never been a flashy phone. It’s grounded, durable and functional. It also has to meet a substantially low price, so unnecessary extras and luxuries have to be ditched.It’s still made mostly of plastic, but it far outweighs its £169 price-tag. The front is simple and clean, with no branding and no buttons of any sort. There’s the smallest hint of flair with a silver-rimmed speaker opening at the top, but that’s it.The metal frame adds some quality and strength to the mix, but I’d like some tougher, less plasticky, buttons. The volume and standby keys on the sides require a good hit of force and they’re a bit mushy, but I’m being overly picky – they're still perfectly functional.The rear panel has been a bit divisive in the TrustedReviews office, and I’m not completely a fan. Gone is the heavily ridged, almost rubbery, feel of the 2015 version and it’s been replaced by a soft-touch textured plastic. It’s grippy, but it feels strange and seems to get oily and greasy very quickly.The once-iconic ‘Moto Dimple’ is getting less and less pronounced with every phone. On the original Moto X it was the perfect spot to place your finger, but now it’s barely noticeable. Above the batwing logo sits the camera and flash, encased in glass and surrounded by a silver oval.Like previous Moto Gs, the back pops off to allow some colourful customisation through sold-separately backplates. This is also where you access the microSD card and SIM slots, meaning you don’t need an annoying SIM tool to access them. Interestingly, the SIM slot works with both a Micro and a Nano card – a nice touch I haven’t seen before.Even though the back comes off, the battery is firmly attached. Sorry to those of you who love replaceable cells. The Moto G4 has also lost its predecessor's water-resistance powers, though it still should escape a trip through the rain unscathed.Moto G4 camera sample low lightSUMMARYOUR SCORE:PROSSo much tech for your cash\u2028Reliable camera\u2028Great screen\u2028No useless software\u2028Handy Moto tweaks\u2028CONSVery big\u2028Divisive textured back\u2028No NFCBEST DEALS FOR MOTOROLA MOTO G4 2016COMPARE PLANSKEY FEATURES5.5-inch 1080p displaySnapdragon 617 CPU2GB RAM16GB storage3,000 mAh battery13MP camera5MP selfie cameraAndroid 6.0.1Manufacturer: MotorolaReview Price: £169.00WHAT IS THE MOTO G4?I've reviewed a lot of flagships phones this year, like the Samsung Galaxy S7 and iPhone 7, but there isn't a better deal out there than the Moto G4 2016. And it's only £169.The budget phone of choice for many, and three-time TrustedReviews Budget Phone of the Year winner, has received an update. And while it’s now officially a Lenovo phone, the magical combination of performance, features and value hasn't been lost.It’s fast, has a great camera for the cost, a bright screen and Nexus-like software. I do have some reservations about the size, but honestly every other affordable phone maker should be worried. Seriously worried.This item is currently on sale , meaning you could bag a bargain. Check out our Black Friday deals for more savings, and get a deal on the Moto G 2016 below:Read also: iPhone 7MOTO G4 – DESIGNThe Moto G has never been a flashy phone. It’s grounded, durable and functional. It also has to meet a substantially low price, so unnecessary extras and luxuries have to be ditched.It’s still made mostly of plastic, but it far outweighs its £169 price-tag. The front is simple and clean, with no branding and no buttons of any sort. There’s the smallest hint of flair with a silver-rimmed speaker opening at the top, but that’s it.Related: Best budget Android phonesThe metal frame adds some quality and strength to the mix, but I’d like some tougher, less plasticky, buttons. The volume and standby keys on the sides require a good hit of force and they’re a bit mushy, but I’m being overly picky – they're still perfectly functional.The rear panel has been a bit divisive in the TrustedReviews office, and I’m not completely a fan. Gone is the heavily ridged, almost rubbery, feel of the 2015 version and it’s been replaced by a soft-touch textured plastic. It’s grippy, but it feels strange and seems to get oily and greasy very quickly.The once-iconic ‘Moto Dimple’ is getting less and less pronounced with every phone. On the original Moto X it was the perfect spot to place your finger, but now it’s barely noticeable. Above the batwing logo sits the camera and flash, encased in glass and surrounded by a silver oval.Like previous Moto Gs, the back pops off to allow some colourful customisation through sold-separately backplates. This is also where you access the microSD card and SIM slots, meaning you don’t need an annoying SIM tool to access them. Interestingly, the SIM slot works with both a Micro and a Nano card – a nice touch I haven’t seen before.Even though the back comes off, the battery is firmly attached. Sorry to those of you who love replaceable cells. The Moto G4 has also lost its predecessor's water-resistance powers, though it still should escape a trip through the rain unscathed.motog4 7My biggest issue with the Moto G4 is the size of the thing. It’s well and truly a phablet, and it’s as wide as the iPhone 6S Plus (though not as tall) making it cumbersome to hold unless you have large hands. It’s a two-handed phone for sure, and my thumb can’t easily move from the top of the screen to the bottom unless I grip it with my palms.The jump from a 5-inch to a 5.5-inch display is clearly the main factor in this growth, but in doing so I feel it loses some of the mass-market appeal that made the previous iterations so great. It’s not heavy or particularly thick, but I have passed it between friends and the vast majority have said it’s too big for them.With Lenovo releasing two versions of the G4 and one boasting a ‘Plus’ branding, it seems odd they’re both 5.5 inches. I’d have much preferred one to stay at a more manageable 5-inch size, or even 4.7-inch, and the other sitting higher above."

 [1] "don't go on spec sheet. Great battery, almost lasts 24 hours with usage of 10 hours of internet and 2 hours of gaming. even with smaller processor, much better experience than redmi and lenovo phones. screen clarity is much better compared to same price phones. no heating issue even with gaming while charging.  [9] "If you are looking for a smartphone at a low cost, then the Moto G4 Play pros outweigh the cons. it seems tough for other manufacturers to beat the Moto G4.There are some minor differences that the lower cost G4 Play has from the G4 and G4 Plus. For example, the G4 Play does not support the karate chop shortcut motion for turning on the flashlight. But if you manage what to expect from a smartphone due to the low cost, then you will likely be satisfied. I actually recommend this device for someone that is on a budget, someone that is getting a smartphone for the first time or someone that is switching from a feature phone for the first time."

 [3] "The Moto G has never been a flashy phone. It’s grounded, durable and functional. It also has to meet a substantially low price, so unnecessary extras and luxuries have to be ditched.It’s still made mostly of plastic, but it far outweighs its £169 price-tag. The front is simple and clean, with no branding and no buttons of any sort. There’s the smallest hint of flair with a silver-rimmed speaker opening at the top, but that’s it.The metal frame adds some quality and strength to the mix, but I’d like some tougher, less plasticky, buttons. The volume and standby keys on the sides require a good hit of force and they’re a bit mushy, but I’m being overly picky – they're still perfectly functional.The rear panel has been a bit divisive in the TrustedReviews office, and I’m not completely a fan. Gone is the heavily ridged, almost rubbery, feel of the 2015 version and it’s been replaced by a soft-touch textured plastic. It’s grippy, but it feels strange and seems to get oily and greasy very quickly.The once-iconic ‘Moto Dimple’ is getting less and less pronounced with every phone. On the original Moto X it was the perfect spot to place your finger, but now it’s barely noticeable. Above the batwing logo sits the camera and flash, encased in glass and surrounded by a silver oval.Like previous Moto Gs, the back pops off to allow some colourful customisation through sold-separately backplates. This is also where you access the microSD card and SIM slots, meaning you don’t need an annoying SIM tool to access them. Interestingly, the SIM slot works with both a Micro and a Nano card – a nice touch I haven’t seen before.Even though the back comes off, the battery is firmly attached. Sorry to those of you who love replaceable cells. The Moto G4 has also lost its predecessor's water-resistance powers, though it still should escape a trip through the rain unscathed.Moto G4 camera sample low lightSUMMARYOUR SCORE:PROSSo much tech for your cash\u2028Reliable camera\u2028Great screen\u2028No useless software\u2028Handy Moto tweaks\u2028CONSVery big\u2028Divisive textured back\u2028No NFCBEST DEALS FOR MOTOROLA MOTO G4 2016COMPARE PLANSKEY FEATURES5.5-inch 1080p displaySnapdragon 617 CPU2GB RAM16GB storage3,000 mAh battery13MP camera5MP selfie cameraAndroid 6.0.1Manufacturer: MotorolaReview Price: £169.00WHAT IS THE MOTO G4?I've reviewed a lot of flagships phones this year, like the Samsung Galaxy S7 and iPhone 7, but there isn't a better deal out there than the Moto G4 2016. And it's only £169.The budget phone of choice for many, and three-time TrustedReviews Budget Phone of the Year winner, has received an update. And while it’s now officially a Lenovo phone, the magical combination of performance, features and value hasn't been lost.It’s fast, has a great camera for the cost, a bright screen and Nexus-like software. I do have some reservations about the size, but honestly every other affordable phone maker should be worried. Seriously worried.This item is currently on sale , meaning you could bag a bargain. Check out our Black Friday deals for more savings, and get a deal on the Moto G 2016 below:Read also: iPhone 7MOTO G4 – DESIGNThe Moto G has never been a flashy phone. It’s grounded, durable and functional. It also has to meet a substantially low price, so unnecessary extras and luxuries have to be ditched.It’s still made mostly of plastic, but it far outweighs its £169 price-tag. The front is simple and clean, with no branding and no buttons of any sort. There’s the smallest hint of flair with a silver-rimmed speaker opening at the top, but that’s it.Related: Best budget Android phonesThe metal frame adds some quality and strength to the mix, but I’d like some tougher, less plasticky, buttons. The volume and standby keys on the sides require a good hit of force and they’re a bit mushy, but I’m being overly picky – they're still perfectly functional.The rear panel has been a bit divisive in the TrustedReviews office, and I’m not completely a fan. Gone is the heavily ridged, almost rubbery, feel of the 2015 version and it’s been replaced by a soft-touch textured plastic. It’s grippy, but it feels strange and seems to get oily and greasy very quickly.The once-iconic ‘Moto Dimple’ is getting less and less pronounced with every phone. On the original Moto X it was the perfect spot to place your finger, but now it’s barely noticeable. Above the batwing logo sits the camera and flash, encased in glass and surrounded by a silver oval.Like previous Moto Gs, the back pops off to allow some colourful customisation through sold-separately backplates. This is also where you access the microSD card and SIM slots, meaning you don’t need an annoying SIM tool to access them. Interestingly, the SIM slot works with both a Micro and a Nano card – a nice touch I haven’t seen before.Even though the back comes off, the battery is firmly attached. Sorry to those of you who love replaceable cells. The Moto G4 has also lost its predecessor's water-resistance powers, though it still should escape a trip through the rain unscathed.motog4 7My biggest issue with the Moto G4 is the size of the thing. It’s well and truly a phablet, and it’s as wide as the iPhone 6S Plus (though not as tall) making it cumbersome to hold unless you have large hands. It’s a two-handed phone for sure, and my thumb can’t easily move from the top of the screen to the bottom unless I grip it with my palms.The jump from a 5-inch to a 5.5-inch display is clearly the main factor in this growth, but in doing so I feel it loses some of the mass-market appeal that made the previous iterations so great. It’s not heavy or particularly thick, but I have passed it between friends and the vast majority have said it’s too big for them.With Lenovo releasing two versions of the G4 and one boasting a ‘Plus’ branding, it seems odd they’re both 5.5 inches. I’d have much preferred one to stay at a more manageable 5-inch size, or even 4.7-inch, and the other sitting higher above."
